[BHU 2013]

(b) Gauss's law
(c) Ohm's law

questions.subject: PHYSICS

questions.ocrQuestion:
Maxwell's equation can be written in the form shown below. if magnetic charge exists and if it is conserved, which of these equations will have to be charged?
[BHU 2012]
(1) \( \nabla . \mathrm{E}=\frac{\rho}{\varepsilon_{0}} \)
(2) \( \nabla . \mathrm{B}=0 \)
(3) \( \nabla \times \mathrm{E}=-\frac{\partial \mathrm{B}}{\partial t} \)
(4) \( \nabla \times \mathbf{B}=\mu_{0} \mathrm{~J}+\mu_{0} \varepsilon_{0} \frac{\partial \mathrm{E}}{\partial t} \)
(a) 2 only
(b) 3 only
(c) 1 and 4
(d) 2 and 3
questions.onlyq_text: Maxwell's equation can be written in the form shown below. if magnetic charge exists and if it is conserved, which of these equations will have to be charged?[BHU 2012](1) \( abla . \mathrm{E}= rac{ ho}{\varepsilon_{0}} \)(2) \( abla . \mathrm{B}=0 \)(3) \( abla imes \mathrm{E}=- rac{\partial \mathrm{B}}{\partial t} \)(4) \( abla imes \mathbf{B}=\mu_{0} \mathrm{~J}+\mu_{0} \varepsilon_{0} rac{\partial \mathrm{E}}{\partial t} \)
questions.sol_html: Gauss Law for magnetism: \( abla \cdot \vec{B} 0 \)- It implies there is no magnetic monopoles.- If there is magnetic monopole: \( abla \cdot \vec{B} eq 0 \)Faraday Law of Induction: \( abla \times \vec{E}-\frac{\partial \vec{B}}{\partial t} \)- The electric field is equal to the negative of the rate of change of the magnetic flux.- If there is magnetic monopole, an extra term (involving the current of magnetic monopoles) must be added to the righthand side of the equation in order to make it self-consistent.
questions.subject: PHYSICS

questions.ocrQuestion:
The Maxwell's equation derived from Faraday's law of electromagnetic induction is
[BHU 2011]
(a) \( \vec{\nabla} \cdot \vec{E}=\frac{\rho}{\varepsilon} \)
(b) \( \vec{\nabla} \cdot \vec{B}=0 \)
(c) \( \vec{\nabla} \times \vec{E}=-\frac{\partial \vec{B}}{\partial t} \)
(d) \( \vec{\nabla} \times \vec{E}=\mu_{0}\left(\vec{J}+\varepsilon \frac{\partial \vec{E}}{\partial t}\right) \)
questions.onlyq_text: The Maxwell's equation derived from Faraday's law of electromagnetic induction is[BHU 2011]
questions.subject: PHYSICS

questions.ocrQuestion:
For electric and magnetic fields. \( \vec{E} \) and \( \vec{B} \), due to a charge density \( \rho(r, t) \) and a current density \( \vec{J}(\vec{r}, \vec{t}) \), which of the following relations is/are always correct?
[JAM 2020]

Where \( \vec{F} \) is the force on a particle with charge q moving with velocity \( \vec{v} \).
(a) \( \vec{\nabla} \times \vec{E}=0 \)
(b) \( \vec{\nabla} \cdot \vec{B}=0 \)
(c) \( \vec{\nabla} \cdot \overrightarrow{\mathrm{J}}-\frac{\partial \rho}{\partial t}=0 \)
(d) \( \vec{F}=q(\vec{E}+\vec{v} \times \vec{B}) \).
questions.onlyq_text: For electric and magnetic fields. \( \vec{E} \) and \( \vec{B} \), due to a charge density \( \rho(r, t) \) and a current density \( \vec{J}(\vec{r}, \vec{t}) \), which of the following relations is/are always correct?[JAM 2020]Where \( \vec{F} \) is the force on a particle with charge q moving with velocity \( \vec{v} \).

questions.ocrQuestion:
For an electromagnetic wave travelling in free space, the electric field is given by \( \vec{E}=100 \cos \left(10^{8} t+k x\right) \hat{j} V / m \). which of the following statements are true?
[JAM 2015]
(a) The wavelength of the wave in meter is \( 6 \pi \)
(b) The corresponding magnetic field is direction along the positive \( \mathrm{z} \)-direction
(c) The poynting vector is direction along the positive \( \mathrm{z} \)-direction
(d) The wave is linearly polarized.
questions.onlyq_text: For an electromagnetic wave travelling in free space, the electric field is given by \( \vec{E}=100 \cos \left(10^{8} t+k x\right) \hat{j} V / m \). which of the following statements are true?[JAM 2015]

options.option: (a) The wavelength of the wave in meter is \( 6 \pi \)
(b) The corresponding magnetic field is direction along the positive \( \mathrm{z} \)-direction
(c) The poynting vector is direction along the positive \( \mathrm{z} \)-direction

questions.ocrQuestion:
The electric field of an electromagnetic wave is given by
\[
\vec{E}=\hat{i} E_{0} \sin (k y-\omega t)
\]
where \( k \) and \( \omega \) respectively denote the wave vector and angular frequency of the wave. \( \hat{i}, \hat{j} \) and \( \hat{k} \) respectively denote the unit vectors in the \( x, y \) and \( z \) directions. The magnetic field \( \vec{B} \) of the wave is given by
(a) \( \hat{k} E_{0} k \sin (k y-\omega t) \)
(b) \( \hat{j} E_{0} \cos (k y-\omega t) \)
(c) \( -\hat{k} \frac{E_{0} \omega}{k} \cos (k y-\omega t) \)
(d) \( -\hat{k} \frac{E_{0} k}{\omega} \sin (k y-\omega t) \)

The magnetic field \( \vec{B} \) of the wave is given by
